* John Panzer <jpanzer@...> [2007-06-28 18:25]:
> There was also an assumption in the W3 WG that they were
> talking about byte range updates, and I think that what we
> really are looking at is infoset level deltas. Which I think
> changes the discussion.

Exactly. The applicability of PUT with Content-Range is quite
limited: you can only modify a single contiguous region of the
resource per request, and it requires that the server support
octet-level addressing on the underlying resource in the first
place. Supporting Content-Range on GET is easy, even if the data
is plucked from a database and then rendered through a template;
supporting Content-Range on PUT in this scenario is… very tricky,
to say the least.

And of course, there’s the gnarly problem of Content-Range
getting dropped in some scenarios.

PATCH, OTOH, has none of these issues. You can modify as many
parts of the resource at once as you want, expressing
modifications at an arbitrary level of abstraction, and failure
in transit is more reliable.
